Name Rascal/Expressions/Values/List/Concatenation

Synopsis Concatenate two lists.
Syntax Exp1 + Exp2
Types
Exp1 Exp2 Exp1 + Exp2
list[T1] list[T2] list[lub(T1,T2)]
list[T1] T2 list[lub(T1,T2)]
T1 list[T2] list[lub(T1,T2)]
Description If both Exp1 and Exp2 have a list as value, the result is the concatenation of these two list values. If one of Exp1 or Exp2 does not have a list as value, it is first converted to a list before the concatenation is computed.
Examples 
rascal>[1, 2, 3] + [4, 5, 6];
list[int]: [1,2,3,4,5,6]
rascal>[1, 2, 3] + 4;
list[int]: [1,2,3,4]
rascal>1 + [2, 3, 4];
list[int]: [1,2,3,4]
Questions
Question 1. When you compute the union of two sets, the number of elements in the result is always:
Greater than or equal the number of elements in both sets.
Greater than the number of elements in both sets.
Smaller than the number of elements in both sets.
Smaller than or equal the number of elements in both sets.

Question 2.
The type of ["Grapefruit", "Bert", "Garlic", "Admiral Sarn"] + ["N", "Slimey the Worm", "Prince Charming", "Redcurrant"] is

Question 3. 
[9, 3] + [-17] ==

Question 4. 
["Grover", "Blueberry", "Mango"] +  == ["Grover","Blueberry","Mango","Ernie","J"]

Question 5. 
{11, -13.10479455176185600} + {14.51230656069717200, -4.732616190581069200} ==
